sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: The objective of this article is to determine the prevalence of parents of children (aged 0–17 years) within a mental health service system and gather contextual data regarding this population.

sec.title: Method:
sec.p: The study uses a census approach. The Census is conducted annually across Central Coast Adult Mental Health Services, NSW, Australia. All five community mental health teams and four acute inpatient units within the service participate, with each team completing Census forms for active clients identified as parents on Census day. The Census form collects data on parents and children including demographic data, parental diagnosis, parental contact and risk factors.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Consecutive data shows 25–28% of active clients are parents. Annually, at least 400 children are identified; approximately 60% reside permanently with their parent with a mental illness.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: The Census is a valuable tool to determine the prevalence of parenthood. Moreover, it collects contextual data on this population. Data show an emerging relationship between parental diagnosis and parental contact. A picture of level of risk across the system has also been highlighted. Results add to the evidence regarding parental mental illness and circumstances of these families. The data clearly articulate a large need for interventions for children of parents with a mental illness (COPMI) within this population, given the high proportion of children who permanently reside with their parent with a mental illness.

kwd-group.kwd: children of parents with a mental illness

body.p: Children living within families experiencing parental mental illness are at greater risk of adverse outcomes than children not living with parental mental illness.1 These children are more likely to experience negative outcomes, including an increased risk of psychological and behavioural problems,2 disruptions in home life and schooling, and development of maladaptive coping strategies.3 Additionally, attachment issues may result because parents with mental illness may have reduced capacity to demonstrate love, security, nurturing and sensitive parenting practices.1,3 The overrepresentation of parental mental illness among families where child maltreatment is identified is also concerning.4

Impacts of parental mental illness can continue well beyond childhood into adolescence and adulthood. An association between maternal mental health problems and poorer academic outcomes for youth has been identified.5 Evidence also suggests up to two-thirds of adult children will experience a psychosocial disorder and/or mental illness.6 Additionally, adult children report childhood neglect, increased caregiver responsibilities (impacting on vocational goals and social relationships), stigma and lack of support, and have been shown to experience lower levels of social functioning, greater work and marriage problems, decreased self-esteem and increased alcohol use.7

Consequently, the provision of appropriate services and interventions to meet the needs of parents with mental illness and their children is essential. A recent systematic review provides evidence that individual, group and family-based interventions can prevent poor outcomes for children of parents with a mental illness.8 Maybery et al. suggest ‘adult mental health services are a central point for interventions to stop the family cycle of mental illness’9 (p.125). Moreover, the provision of preventive family interventions and psychoeducation with parents within adult mental health settings has demonstrated positive outcomes for children as well as improving parenting practices.10 Acknowledging and working with children has been shown to have positive impacts on family functioning and children’s understanding of parental mental illness, and decreased internalising problems for children.11

Historically, mental health services have been slow to respond to this need, with children of parents with mental illness often referred to as ‘hidden’.12 Barriers that may explain why these children remain ‘hidden’ include a lack of family- and child-friendly policies; limited clinician knowledge, skills and understanding of their role when working with families; and an inability to identify consumers who are parents.13,14 Confounding this, workers may be trained to work with parents or children but not both.11

Adequate identification of the number of parents and children affected by mental illness within a mental health service system is one mechanism to inform the need for service provision and to raise awareness of the need for a family-focused approach. Indeed, the 2009 Council of Australian Governments’ National Framework for Protecting Australia’s Children emphasises the need to increase the capacity and capability of adult services to identify and respond to the needs of children at risk.15 Moreover, highlighting to workers the numbers of parent clients has shown some effect in changing worker attitudes to become more family focussed.13

Within Central Coast Mental Health Services (CCMHS) in NSW, Australia, clinical practice identifies individual parents through assessment and triage. However, the ability to gain a service-wide perspective of parents and their children and contextual data about this population has been limited. The Mental Health and Parenting Census (Census) was developed to address this limitation. The Census is an annual ‘snapshot’ of the parent client population, allowing CCMHS to examine issues regarding parental mental illness on a broader scale. This paper will describe the Census process, and compare and discuss Census results from 2008 to 2011. Implications for use of Census data will be discussed.

sec.title: The Mental Health and Parenting Census
sec.p: The Census is conducted annually across CCMHS. The Census identifies the prevalence of parenthood amongst active clients of CCMHS, gathering contextual data about these parents and their children.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Clinicians complete a Census form for each active client identified as a parent of child/children aged 0–17 years and/or pregnant. Data collected include demographic information, mental health status, parental contact and risk factors for children. A full description of the Census development and implementation has been outlined by the first author (DH);16 a copy of the Census form is available on request.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: On Census day, all teams within CCMHS (five community mental health teams and four acute mental health inpatient units) complete Census forms for identified parent clients. The overall number of active clients for each clinician is also indicated on the Census form. This is used to determine the total number of active clients (parent and non-parent clients) across the service on Census day.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: Census data are entered into Statistical Package for Social Science (SPSS) version 19 for Windows.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The Census is an effective and accurate process for generating prevalence data regarding the number of parent clients (of children 0–17 years) within a mental health service system. The findings show that in any one year 25–28% of active mental health service clients are parents of no fewer than 400 children aged 0–17 years. Moreover, approximately 60% of these children reside permanently with their parent. This finding is consistent with evidence from other community mental health settings which report 57% of minor children live with a parent with mental illness.17

The Census provides important contextual information about these families. Consecutive data indicate a relationship between parental diagnosis and parental contact. Although children of a parent with a psychotic disorder are less likely to reside permanently with them, our results demonstrate that 34–56% of these children permanently reside with their parent. This dispels the often-held myth that children do not reside with a parent with a serious mental illness.

An indication of the levels of risk and vulnerability for these families is also captured by the Census. The proportion of children residing with parents with current or past DV and/or AOD issues has been determined. Modifications to the response options for these variables may explain some of the larger variances seen. It will be interesting to note how this data evolves in future years. Furthermore, 28–39% of children had current or previous Community Services involvement, demonstrating that vulnerabilities within these families are regularly identified and acted on.

sec.title: Future directions
sec.p: The Census data can inform service planning and capacity-building initiatives that strengthen CCMHS response to future needs. An evaluation of the national COPMI web-based training resource ‘Keeping families and children in mind’ reported changes in knowledge, skills and confidence, and heightened awareness of the need to work with families and children for mental health clinicians.18 CCMHS COPMI coordinators facilitate workshops for clinicians utilising this resource. To strengthen service capacity, an information kit for families has been developed. A clinical tools and tips guide is also available to support mental health clinicians to identify and respond to parenting issues. Additionally, the development of partnerships with non-government agencies to implement programs such as SMILES (The Simplifying Mental Illness and Life Enhancement Skills Program), which enhances coping skills for children living in a family with mental illness,19 will also address COPMI needs.

Census results highlight the need for a more strategic and systematic approach to addressing COPMI issues across the area. Subsequently, the CCMHS COPMI implementation committee will oversee COPMI initiatives across CCMHS and address state priorities as identified in NSW Children of Parents with a Mental Illness (COPMI): Framework for Mental Health Services 2010–2015.20 Census data has informed the pilot enhancements to the CCMHS electronic database to record COPMI service milestones and outcomes.

A file audit project to determine consistency of Census data compared to that reported in client medical records (completed in 2010) demonstrated the Census has some limitations. A complete discussion of these findings is beyond the scope of this paper. However, some inconsistencies were noted. Although higher levels of consistency were seen relating to basic demographic variables, less consistency was seen relating to risk variables. This may reflect how information is documented within medical records, the accessibility of this information for clinicians or the complexity of assessing risk.

Within CCMHS, the Census has increased awareness of mental health and parenting issues. Additionally, the Census has provided opportunities to consider service planning based on need and has informed the development of CCMHS services, including the Whole Family Team and Perinatal Infant Mental Health Team. It is envisaged that the Census data can further inform the development of initiatives to support parents and children into the future.
